FOREWORD
The Puṟattiraṭṭu is an anthology of 1,570 stanzas. It may be.
assigned to the latter half of the 15th century, and it must have
been put together at a period when many Buddhist and Jaina
works, now lost, were available. Kamban’s Rāmāvatāram is the
latest work represented in the collection, if we leave aside the
one stanza ascribed to Naḷaveṇbā in some of the Mss. and to
Bhāratam in others.
The anthology is of considerable importance to students of
Tamil literature. It brings to light many works which are other-
wise unknown, ''e. g''., Āśiriyamālai, Irumpal-kāñci, Nārada-caritai,
Śanti-purāṇam and Perumporuḷ-viḷakkam. It gives many excerpts
from works known only by name or by a few extracts preserved
by later scholiasts ; among such works are Kuṇḍalakēśi, Takaḍūr-
yāttirai, Muttoḷḷāyiram and Vaḷaiyāpati. It includes extracts from
the missing portions of works now accessible in more or less exten-
sive fragments, e.g, Patiṟṟuppattu, Paripāṭal, Bhāratam and Ciṟu-
pañcamūlam. It cites from certain works, a few stanzas which,
however, are not found in their published editions. Lastly, it
offers better texts of many poems already printed from inferior
manuscripts.
From another standpoint also, the collection is important. It
follows, in its subject analysis, the scheme of the Tirukkuṟaḻ and
forms an excellent supplement to that great work. The poems
excerpted are of a high order, and constitute fine examples of a
simple, terse and forceful idiom from which we have much to
learn.
This anthology seems to have been once very popular, for we
find that there are also two shorter recensions of it. The stanzas
included in these recensions are given in Appendix IV.
Mr. S. Somasundara Desikar, now of the Tamil Lexicon office,
printed in 1918 the first 247 stanzas. Extracts from Puṟattiraṭṭu
pertaining to Vaḷaiyāpati, Kuṇḍalakeśi, Muttoḷḷāyiram, Āśiriya-
mālai, Perumporuḷ-viḷakkam, Nārada-caritai, etc., have. appeared
in the pages of Sen Tamil (Vols. I, III, V, VI, VIII and XIV). With
these exceptions, the work has remained unpublished till now.
A list of the manuscripts used in preparing the present edition
is given separately together with some particulars about them.
xii
After the text had been printed, I gained access, through the
kindness of Mahamahopadhyaya Dr. V. Swaminatha Aiyar, to a
valuable paper manuscript in his possession. The variant readings
given by this manuscript are noted in Appendix V. Again, one of
the cadjan manuscripts belongs to the Tanjore Palace Library.
The rules of that library are strict and do not permit the loan of any
manuscript, and at my request Mr. S. Subramanya Sastrigal,
Retired Sanskrit Pandit of the Kalyanasundaram High School,
Tanjore, kindly noted down the readings on the proofs which I sent
to him. Another cadjan manuscript belonging to the Tamil Sangam
Library was compared by me at Madura with the assistance of
Mr. T. K. Ramanuja Aiyangar, Assistant Editor, Sen Tamil.
In noting readings, I have adopted the practice which I have
been following for some years now. In this system, the text is not
encumbered with any superior numbers. In the footnote, the
readings of each stanza are noted against the number of the cīr
where the variation occurs. I owe this neat system to the sugges-
tion of my friend Mr. P. N. Appuswami Aiyar, B.A., B.L., Advocate,
Madras. By its simplicity, it enables one to present the manuscript
material in its entirety, including scribal errors. It must be noted
that even these errors might ultimately prove a valuable guide in
arriving at a correct reading.
Beyond stanza 1305, the paper manuscript of the Government
Oriental Manuscripts Library was the only source and the text was
obviously corrupt at many points. 1 owe a few suggestions of
possible readings to the kindness of Dr. V. Swaminatha Aiyar and
Mahavidvan R. Raghava Aiyangar of the Annamalai University.
Their suggestions are included in Appendix V.
In comparing manuscripts and in proof-reading, I was assisted
by Mr. M. Arunachalam Pillai, B.A., of the Government Trans-
lator’s Office, Madras. Vidvan V. Venkatarajulu Reddiyar, Junior
Lecturer in Tamil, O. R. Institute and Vidvan A. Narayanaswami,
Research Student in Tamil, O. R. Institute, were also of occasional
help. Mr. T. K. Rajamarthandam Pillai, B. A., Tamil Lexicon Office,
made for me a copy of the manuscript belonging to the Government
Oriental Manuscripts Library.
I am happy to acknowledge my indebtedness to the above
scholars and authorities who lent me manuscripts of this work and
helped me in other Ways.
xiii
The matter contained in the Tamil Introduction appeared in a
series of articles on “Tokai-nūl” in Kalaimagal. By the
courtesy of its editor, Mr. R. Narayanaswami Aiyar, B.A., B. L.,
I have incorporated the articles here with such changes as were
suggested by further study.
The Proprietor of the G. S. Press has devoted considerable
care to the neat and accurate printing of the book and my thanks
are due to him.
UNIVERSITY OF MADRAS, S. VAIYAPURI PILLAI,
10th. March, 1938. Reader in Tamil
NOTE ON THE REPRINT
The First edition of this classical anthology having been
exhausted, a reprint had to be issued urgently to meet the public
demand. In this reprint, the Tamil Introduction has been slightly
modified in a few places. A. stanza from Āśiriyamālai (St. 1332) has
been split into two separate stanzas as originally suggested by Dr.
V. Swaminatha Aiyar and the new stanza bears the number 1332 a.
No other material alteration is introduced.
UNIVERSITY OF MADRAS, S. VAIYAPURI PILLAI,
20th July 1939. Reader in Tamil.

xviii
eṉpar āciriyar mattēyu ārnālṭu. karuttulakukkum kalaiyulakuk
kum taṉippaṭṭa pukaḻum perumaiyum amaivataṉ kāraṇam eṉ
ṉeṉiṉ, ivvīrulakattum pōlippulamai ciṟitum iṭam peṟā
teṉpatēyām eṉṟu ciṟanta pireñcu āciriyaroruvar (Sainte
Beuve) kūṟukiṉṟār. kavitait tuṟai yeṉpatu karuttum kalaiyum
oruṅkuviḷaṅkum iṭamākum. kavitaiyō makkaḷatu tuṉpan tuṭait

avarkaṭku uṟuti payappatā yuḷḷatu. ivvakai piyalpuḷḷa viṭat
til pōlippulamaiyāl ettaṉai kēṭu viḷaivatākum eṉpataṉai
nammavar uṇaravillai.
pōlippulamaiyāl viḷaiyuṅ kēṭukaḷ
ippōlippulamai yeṉṉuṅ kaḷai mikkiruttaliṉālē kavitaip

kaḷummika ariyareṉṟē collavēṇṭum. kavitva
caktiyeṉpatu kāṇutaṟ karitāyuḷḷatu. pāṭuvō
ruḷ oru cilar yāppilakkaṇan tavaṟātapaṭi oḻuṅ
kāka yāppukkaḷ puṇarkkiṟārkaḷ. ivvakai yāp

ikkavikaḷil nūlāciriyaṉatu anaṅkatulyamāṉa pēraḻaku mutaliyaṉa

taṉavām. ivaiyāṟum maturaikkuriyaṉa. ivaṟṟai

koṉṟāṉ kolaccoṉṉāṉ kūcavaṟut tāṉaṭṭāṉ
tiṉṟāṉ vilakkiṭāṉ ceṉṟoṉṟu—koṉṟavaṉaik

paṭṭaḻaṉṟu vīḻvār pataittu.

lv
mēlāka aintu ceyyuṭkaḷ kāṇappaṭukiṉṟaṉa. avaṟṟuḷ,
‘uruvaḻikku muṇmait tiruvaḻikkum’ (puṟat. 1072) eṉpatu
naḷaveṇpāviṉuḷḷum vantuḷḷatu. ēṉaiya 4 ceyyuṭkaḷum
varumāṟu :
uṟṟa nalattā ṉoḻukātu nāṇāḷum
peṟṟava ṉēviyacoṟ pēṇātu—maṟṟavaṉmuṉ
tiṇṇuruvaṅ koṇṭu cilaikku mavaḷaṉṟē
peṇṇuruvaṅ koṇṭatōr pēy. (puṟat. 84)
vāṉcēriṟ puḷḷañcā vallaril cuṟṟiya
kāṉcēriṉ māṉiṉ kaṇamañcā—vāṉcēr
cikara varaicēriṟ ṟēṉañcā vañcā
mikunīrk kayañcēriṉ mīṉ. (” 613)
yāvar variṉu metirēṟkun teyvamaṭap
pāvai yakattiruntum pāḻaṉṟē—mēviṉarait
taṇṇār karatalattāṟ ṟaḷḷāvāyt tāmumoru
kaṇṇāki niṟkiṉṟa kaṇ. (” 689)
kalivara lūḻiyiṉ vāḻkkai kaṭintu
malipukaḻ vēṇṭu maṉattar—olikaṭalcūḻ
maṇṇakalam vēṇṭātu vāṉvēṇṭi yīṇṭiṉār
puṇṇiyamām pōrkkaḷattup pōntu. (puṟat. 1346)
patippāḷar ‘paḻaiya pāratappāṭṭukkaḷ’ eṉpataṉkīḻk koṭut

nalvā ṉavarkāṇa nammai yamarakattu
velvāṉ virumpiya vēlvēntaik—kolvā
ṉuṉakkē yurimai yuḷateṉiṉu mippō
reṉakkē taruvā ṉiṟai. (puṟat. 1311)
muḻuvatum akappaṭṭuḷḷa nūlkaḷ
iṉi, muḻuvatum akappaṭṭu veḷiyiṭappeṟṟuḷ nūlkaḷuḷ
oru cilavaṟṟiṟkum puṟattiraṭṭu utavukiṉṟatu. nūlkaḷ ciṟantaṉa
vāyiṉ, palarum kaṟṟup pōṟṟutaṟkuriya
takutiyum poruḷ viḷakkamu muṭaiyavāyiṉ,
annūṟpiratikaḷ tamiḻ nāṭṭil mikap palavāyk
kiṭaippaṉavām. piratikaḷ mikuntōṟum pāṭa
pētaṅkaḷum mikaicceyyuṭkaḷum perukak kāṇappaṭum. nāḷaṭaivil
uṇmaiyāṉa pāṭaṅkaḷai varaiyaṟuppatum nūṟkuriya ceyyuṭ
ṭokai iṉaitteṉat tuṇivatum eḷitil iyalātavāy muṭiyum.
piḻaikaḷum mikutiyākap palkutaṟku iṭamuṇṭu. ceyyuṭṭokai
varaiyaṟai, pāṭa niccayam piḻaitirutta mākiya immūṉṟaṟkum

kaḷavaḻi
kaḷavaḻināṟpatu eṉṉuṅ kīḻkkaṇakku nūlaiyeṭuttukkoḷka.
itaṉkaṇiṉṟum 10 ceyyuṭkaḷ puṟattiraṭṭiṟ
cērkkappeṟṟuḷḷaṉa (1418-1427). ivaṟṟuḷ
iṟutic ceyyuḷ varumāṟu :
paṭaippolitār maṉṉar parūukkuṭar māntik
kuṭaippuṟattut tuñcu mikalaṉ-— iṭaippolinta

ṉiṉṟum 319 ceyyuṭkaḷ puṟattiraṭṭil tokuk
kappaṭṭuḷḷaṉa. iṅṅaṉam tokukkappaṭṭavaṟṟuḷ,
aṟiyāmai yōṭiḷamai yāvatā māṅkē
ceṟiyap paṭuvatāñ celvam—ciṟiya
piṟaipeṟṟa vāṇutalāy tāṉēyā ṭumpēy
paṟaipeṟṟā lāṭātō pāyntu. (puṟat. 1139)

amaiyap poruḷillā rāṟṟātā reṉpa
timaiyat taṉaiyārka ṇillai—cimaiya
nakaiyē rilaṅkaruvi nalvarai nāṭa
nakaiyētā ṉāṟṟi viṭum. (puṟat. 1107)

(cintā. mūṉṟām patippu, pak. 187, 191, 211, 298, 548, 584)
uraiyiṉṟiyum kāṇappaṭukiṉṟaṉaveṉa vuṇarttiyirukkiṟārkaḷ.
iṅṅaṉam mikaiyākap piratikaḷiluḷḷa ceyyuṭkaḷeṉa mēṟ
kāṭṭiya iraṇṭaṉaiyum koḷḷutal kūṭum. itaṟkēṟpa, mūṉṟām
patippiṉ mukavuraiyil,
‘ēṭṭup puttakaṅkaḷaic cōtitta poḻutu iraṇṭu paḻam piratikaḷil

kiṭaittapiṉ veḷiyiṭappaṭum.’

cūḷāmaṇi
cintāmaṇiyiṉuñ ciṟantatāka matikkappaṭuñ cūḷāmaṇi yeṉṟa
arumpeṟaṟ kāviyattiṉiṉṟum 79 ceyyuṭkaḷ
puṟattiraṭṭiṟ kōkkappaṭṭuḷḷaṉa. avaṟṟuḷ
mūṉṟu ceyyuṭkaḷ srī ci. vai. tāmōtaram piḷḷaiyavarkaḷatu
cūḷāmaṇip patippiṟ kāṇappaṭavillai. avai varumāṟu:
kaḷavi ṉākiya kāraṟi vuḷḷaṉmiṉ
viḷaivil vevviṉai vīvil katikaḷuḷ
uḷaiya vuḷḷaḻit toṉṟala vētaṉai
vaḷaiya vāṅki varutta muṟukkumē. (puṟat. 308)
koṉṟuyir naṭuṅkac ceṉṟu kolaittoḻiṟ karuvi yēnti
niṉṟeri nuṭaṅku kaṇṇāṟ pāvamē niṉaintu cettār
ceṉṟeri narakil vīḻvar cevvaṉē tuṉpa mañci
naṉṟiyil kolaiyi ṉīṅki naṟṟavam purimi ṉeṉṟāṉ. (” 338)
kolaiyi ṉīṅkumiṉ koṇmi ṉulakiṉuḷ
talaiva ṉallaṟan takka teṉavuvan
talaiyi ṉīṅkiya vavvula keytutal
muṉaivar coṉṉa muṭivitu vākumē. (” 339)
piḷḷaiyavarkaḷ patippitta cūḷāmaṇi nūṟpiratikaḷum ippōtu

koṇṭē patippitkirukkiṟārkaḷ. pala piratikaḷ kiṭaikkumeṉat
terikiṉṟapaṭiyāl tiruntiya patippoṉṟu veḷivarutal nalamākum.

oṉṟiya poruḷkoṭut tuvantu koṇṭavaṉ
naṉṟitu veṉṟavaṉ nāviṟ peytavaṉ

1531. aṉṉaiyuṅ kōlkoṇ ṭalaikku mayalārum
eṉṉai yaḻiyuñcoṟ colluvar—nuṇṇilaiya
teṅkuṇṭa tērai paṭuvaḻip paṭṭēṉyāṉ
tiṇṭēr vaḷavaṉ ṟiṟattu.
1532. nīru niḻalumpōl nīṇṭa varuḷuṭaiya
ūrirē yeṉṉai yuyakkoṇmiṉ—pōriṟ
pukaluṅ kaḷiyāṉaip pūḻiyarkōk kōtaik
kaḻalumeṉ ṉeñcaṅ kiṭantu. ( ,, )
1533. pulavi puṟakkoṭuppaṉ pulliṭiṉā ṇiṟpaṉ
kalavi kaḷimayaṅkik kāṇēṉ—nilaviyacīr
maṇṇāḷuñ ceṅkōl vaḷavaṉai yāṉitaṉṟō
kaṇṇārak kaṇṭaṟiyā vāṟu. ( ,, )
1534. kaiya tavaṉkaṭaluṭ caṅkamāṟ pūṇṭatuvuñ
ceyyacaṅ kīṉṟa ceḻumuttāl—meyyatuvu
maṉporu vēṉmāṟaṉ vārpotiyiṟ cantaṉamāl
eṉpeṟā vāṭumeṉ ṟōḷ. ( ,, )
1535. nāṇākkāṟ peṇmai nalaṉaḻiyu muṉṉiṉṟu
kāṇākkāṟ kaivaḷaiyuñ cōrumāl-—kāṇēṉāṉ
vaṇṭevvan tīrtār vayamāṉ vaḻutiyaik
kaṇṭevvan tīrvatō rāṟu. ( ,, )
1536. vāriya peṇṇai varukurumpai vāyttaṉapōl
ēriya vāyiṉu meṉceyyum— kūriya
kōṭṭāṉait teṉṉaṉ kuḷircān taṇiyakalaṅ
kōṭṭumaṇ koḷḷā mulai. ( ,, )
1537. ēṟpak kuṭaintāṭi lēcuva rallākkāl
māṟṟi yiruntā ḷeṉavuraippar—vēṟkaṇṇāy
kolyāṉai māṟaṉ kuḷirpuṉal vaiyainī
rellā meṉakkō riṭar. ( ,, )

niṉkālmēl vaippeṉeṉ kaiyiraṇṭum—naṉpāṟ
karaiyuriñci mīṉpiṟaḻuṅ kāvirinīr nāṭaṟ
kuraiyāyō yāṉuṟṟa nōy. ( ,, )

aṉṉaiyu miṉṉa ḷeṉavuraiyal—piṉṉaiyun

1541. kaṭaṟṟāṉaik kōtaiyaik kāṇkoṭāḷ vīṇil
aṭaittāḷ taṉikkatava maṉṉai—yaṭaikkumēl
āyiḻaiyā yeṉṉai yavaṉmē leṭutturaippār

1542. vaḷaiyavāy nīṇṭatōḷ vāṭkaṇā yaṉṉai
iḷaiyaḷāy mūttilaḷ kollō—taḷaiyaviḻtār
maṇkoṇṭa tāṉai maṟaṅkaṉalvēl maraṟaṉaik
kaṇkoṇṭu nōkkaleṉ pāḷ.
1543. koṭipāṭit tērpāṭik koytaṇṭār māṟaṉ
muṭipāṭi muttāram pāṭit—toṭiyulakkai
kaimmaṉaiyi lōccap peṟuveṉō yāṉumōr
ammaṉaik kāva luḷēṉ. ( ,, )
1544. kutalaip paruvattē kōḻikkō māṉai
vatuvai peṟukeṉṟā ḷaṉṉai—atupōy
viḷaintavā viṉṟu viyaṉkāṉal veṇṭērt
tuḷaṅakunīr māmaruṭṭi yaṟṟu. ( ,, )

1550. taḷaiyaviḻum pūṅkōtait tāyarē yāvi

vaṉkaṇṇaṉ vāṇmāṟaṉ mālyāṉai taṉṉuṭaṉvan

kūrārvēṉ māṟaṉeṉ kaippaṟṟa—vārā

kaṉavu miḻantirunta vāṟu. ( ,, )

pāḷaiyiṟ ṟēṉṟoṭukkum pāypuṉa ṉīrnāṭṭuk
